title: 107_s3096
content: The Act may be cited as the "Ballistics, Law Assistance, and Safety Technology Act" or the "BLAST Act" and its purposes are outlined. The "Ballistics, Law Assistance, and Safety Technology Act" aims to increase public safety by assisting law enforcement in solving gun-related crimes through ballistics technology. It requires ballistics testing of new firearms for sale and those in custody of Federal agencies to aid in identifying firearms used in crimes. Additionally, it adds ballistics testing to existing firearms enforcement programs. SEC. 3. DEFINITION OF BALLISTICS. Amends Section 921(a) of title 18, United States Code to define ballistics as a comparative analysis of fired bullets and cartridge casings to identify the firearm used. Amendment to Section 923 of title 18, United States Code requires licensed manufacturers or importers to test fire firearms, prepare ballistics images, and store records in a computerized database. The amendment to Section 923 of title 18, United States Code mandates licensed manufacturers or importers to test fire firearms, store fired bullets and cartridge casings as specified, and receive assistance in acquiring ballistics equipment. No civil liability is created except for civil penalties under this section. The amendment mandates licensed manufacturers or importers to acquire ballistics equipment, develop a database of ballistics images, provide education on ballistics, and coordinate with law enforcement to curb firearm-related crime and trafficking. The Attorney General and the Secretary are required to establish a computer system for accessing ballistics records, promote training for ballistics examiners, and submit reports to the Senate Judiciary Committee annually. The Secretary must submit a report to the Senate and House Judiciary Committees on the impact of the section, including the use of ballistics records in criminal investigations, accessibility across jurisdictions, and statistical evaluation of test programs. The Ballistics, Law Assistance, and State Technology Act authorizes funding for ballistics equipment, testing sites, personnel salaries, and research. Mandatory ballistics testing of firearms is required by the Secretary and the Attorney General. The Ballistics, Law Assistance, and State Technology Act mandates ballistics testing of firearms by the Attorney General and the Secretary of the Treasury. The amendment will take effect once the ballistics systems of the Department of Justice and the Department of the Treasury are interoperable for mandatory testing of new firearms. The Ballistics, Law Assistance, and State Technology Act mandates ballistics testing of firearms by the Attorney General and the Secretary of the Treasury. Section 923(m)(1) of title 18, United States Code, will require mandatory ballistics testing of new firearms five years after the enactment of the Act. Section 923(m)(6) will be effective immediately upon enactment. SEC. 5. PRIVACY RIGHTS OF LAW ABIDING CITIZENS. Ballistics information of individual guns may not be used for prosecutorial purposes unless law enforcement officials have a reasonable belief that a crime has been committed and that ballistics information would assist in the investigation.
